# Cyborgs Cyborgs are man-machine hybrids, purpose-built by the [textlink="robotics" link="Robotics"] division of science for a variety of duties across the station. Bound by [color=cyan]silicon laws[/color] which they follow strictly, and religiously, they serve the crew unconditionally, most of the time.
## Basic Components
All cyborgs are built on a endoskeleton, which can be crafted at an [color=#a4885c]Exosuit Fabricator[/color]. Further assembly steps can be followed by [color=#a4885c]examining[/color] it. Once built, further upgrades, such as additional tools, and longer battery life can be done with modules and a better power cell, respectively.
In addition, newly built cyborgs need a [color=#a4885c]brain[/color] able to interface with the body. There are two main types of such, both of which are able to speak independently, should the chassis be decommissioned, exchanged, or otherwise [color=red]suffer a unscheduled dissassembly[/color]; - The [color=#a4885c]Man-Machine Interface[/color] or MMI for short, is an apparatus able to faciliate communication between a biological brain and electronic components, enabling those suffering from major workplace accidents to continue serving their crew, long after their body is gone. - The [color=#a4885c]Positronic Brain[/color] or PB for short, is an entirely artificial brain, capable of spotaneous neural activity. The time for the synthetic neurons to descramble can wildly vary, but they allow for the creation of cyborgs without having to extract a brain from someone.
Both brains can be fabricated without requiring any additional research.
## Chassis While all cyborgs share the same endoskeleton, not all share the same [color=#a4885c]chassis[/color]. The chassis determines what [color=#a4885c]modules[/color] the cyborg can have, along with the [color=#a4885c]departmental radio channel[/color] they correspond to. By default, they will always have access to [color=violet]Science[/color] and [color=green]station-wide[/color] frequencies, along with having [color=#a4885c]all-access[/color].
If you wish to change the chassis of an already existing cyborg, you have to construct a whole new one, limbs and frame included. The brain, power cell, and modules [italic](if it can fit in the new chassis, that is,)[/italic] can be carried over from the old chassis, if desired.
## Modules
A cyborg isn't able to do much without [color=#a4885c]modules[/color]. These printed circuit boards are specific to cyborgs and grant additonal functionality to the synthetic creatures. As stated before, some modules are specific to a [color=#a4885c]chassis[/color] with only exception being [color=violet]science[/color] modules, and cannot be fitted elsewhere. These exclusive modules are usually marked with their corresponding department's colors.
Additional modules with advanced, or novel capabilities can be acquired through new [textlink="technologies" link="Technologies"] from your scientists.
